  4. Crime in England and Wales

Crime in England and Wales: year ending December 2018

Crime against households and adults, also including data on crime experienced by children, and crimes against businesses and society.

This is the latest release. View previous releases.

Contact:
Email Meghan Elkin

Release date:
25 October 2018

Next release:
To be announced

Table of contents

  1. Main points
  2. Analysis of crime trends
  3. Crime data
  4. Glossary
  5. Measuring this data
  6. Strengths and limitations
  7. Related links

Print this statistical bulletin

Download as PDF

1. Main points

  • Overall levels of crime continue to fall, with no significant change to the long-term trend.
  • Police reported a 6% increase in offences involving knives or sharp instruments, a 6% increase in the number of homicides, and a 2% decrease in the number of police recorded offences involving firearms.
  • 8% increase in overall theft offences estimated by the Crime Survey for England and Wales (CSEW), mainly driven by a 20% increase in “other household theft”.
  • Police reported a 6% increase in offences involving knives or sharp instruments, a 6% increase in the number of homicides, and a 2% decrease in the number of police recorded offences involving firearms.
  • Estimated 2% increase in vehicle offences reported by the police, due largely to a 9% increase in the subcategory of “theft or unauthorised taking of a motor vehicle”.
  • Police reported an 11% increase in robbery, and a 3% decrease in burglaries.
! Warning An increase in the number of crimes recorded by the police does not necessarily mean the level of crime has increased. See the Strengths and limitations section for more information.

Back to table of contents

Statistician's comment

Commenting on today’s figures, Alexa Bradley from the Office for National Statistics Centre for Crime and Justice said:

“When we look at the overall level of crime, there has been no significant change over the last year. However, it is important to look at each crime type separately because the picture is very mixed. Even within crime types we have seen differences. Robbery and vehicle offences have increased whereas burglary has decreased. Lower-volume high-harm violence involving knives has risen, whereas offences involving firearms have decreased.”

2. Analysis of crime trends

Overall estimates of crime

Figure 1: Crime estimated by the survey has not changed significantly over the last year

England and Wales, year ending December 1981 to year ending December 2018

CSEW estimates excluding fraud and computer misuse
CSEW estimates excluding fraud and computer misuse year ending December 2018

● CSEW estimates excluding fraud and computer misuse: 10,432
Source: Office for National Statistics - Crime Survey for England and Wales
Download this chart
Image .csv .xls

Over recent decades we have seen continued falls in overall levels of crime but in the last year there has been no significant change. However, it is important to look at individual crime types as the total figure hides variation both within and across different types of offence.

Figure 2: 7% increase in the number crimes recorded by the police

England and Wales, December 1981 to year ending December 2018

Police recorded crime (old counting rules)
Police recorded crime (new counting rules)
Police recorded crime (after NCRS)
Dec 18Mar 15Mar 11Mar 07Mar 03Dec 98Dec 94Dec 90Dec 86Dec 82
02,000,0004,000,0006,000,0008,000,000
Number of offences
Mar 13
● Police recorded crime (after NCRS) : 4,063,571
Source: Home Office - Police recorded crime
Download this chart
Image .csv .xls

Rises seen over recent years reflect a combination of factors, including continuing improvements to recording processes and practices, more victims reporting crime, and genuine increases in some types of crime. Police recorded crime statistics provide a good measure of the crime-related demand on the police. It is not possible to estimate the relative contribution of each factor, but as a general measure of crime the CSEW is the preferred source. Police recorded crime statistics provide a good measure of the crime-related demand on the police.

! Warning For many types of offence, police recorded crime figures do not provide a reliable measure of crime trends. Inspections carried out by Her Majesty's Inspectorate of Constabulary, Fire & Rescue Services have highlighted concerns over the quality and consistency of crime recording practices in police forces. Recording improvements are known to have contributed to rises seen over the last 5 years.

Violent crime

Figure 3: The Crime Survey for England and Wales shows long-term reductions in violent crime but little change in recent years

The CSEW shows that the level of lower-harm violent offences has not changed. The CSEW provides the best measure of overall trends in violent crime, giving a good measure of the more common but less harmful offences. The latest estimate indicates a continuation of the relatively stable levels of violent crime seen over the last four years.

Homicide

Figure 4: Homicides have decreased following increases over the last four years

England and Wales, year ending March 2003 to year ending March 2019
Mar 19Mar 17Mar 15Mar 13Mar 11Mar 09Mar 07Mar 05Mar 03
02505007501,0001,250
Mar 06
● Homicide: 764
Source: Home Office – Police recorded crime
Download this chart
Image .csv .xls

An upward trend in homicides seen over the last four years contrasts with the downward trend over the previous decade. Despite this, the rate of homicide in the population remains very low, at 12 homicides per 1 million people. Trends in homicide can be affected by events with multiple homicide victims, for example, the terrorist attacks in London and Manchester in 2017.

Knives and sharp instruments

Figure 8: Rising trend in crimes involving knives or sharp instruments driven by increases in assaults with injury or assaults with intent to cause serious harm and robberies

Download this chart
Image .csv .xls

The past four years have seen a rise in the number of recorded offences involving a knife or sharp instrument, following an initial downward trend. This is the highest number since the year ending March 2011, the earliest point for which comparable data are available.

! Warning This figure excludes Greater Manchester Police (GMP), because their data is not comparable. Including GMP, there were 44,443 knife or sharp instrument offences in the year ending December 2019.

The latest rise in theft was mainly driven by a 23% increase in "theft from outside a dwelling". The CSEW is our most reliable indicator for long-term trends, particularly for the more common types of crime experienced by the general population. It captures more minor thefts which are less likely to be reported to the police. The latest rise was mainly driven by a 23% increase in "theft from outside a dwelling".

Burglary, robbery and vehicle theft

Figure 12: Fall in police recorded burglary but rises in police recorded robbery and vehicle offences

England and Wales, year ending March 2003 to year ending March 2019

Download this chart
Image .csv .xls

The latest trends in burglary showed a fall, following small increases seen over the last two years. Police recorded crime data can help identify short-term changes in some types of theft offences, including burglary which is thought to be generally well-reported by victims and well-recorded by the police. The latest trends in burglary showed a fall, following small increases seen over the last two years.

The number of robbery offences recorded by the police indicate that the occurance type of theft (invloving the use or threat of violence) continued to rise. Recording improvements are also likely to have contributed, but the impact is thought to be less pronounced than for some other crime types.

Rises seen over the last three years across the range of vehicle offences, including theft of and theft from vehicle, have continued. Police recorded crime data can help identify short-term changes in some types of theft offences, including vehicle offences which are thought to be generally well-reported by victims and well-recorded by the police.

Criminal Damage

Estimates of overall criminal data experienced by the general population showed no change following long term declines. However, within the category of Criminal Damage there was a 14% increase in criminal damage to a vehicle estimated by the CSEW (to 811,000 offences). There was a 21% decrease in arson and other criminal damage offences estimated by the CSEW (to 324,000 offences).

Fraud

Figure 13: CAMIS data show an increase in plastic card fraud reported to UK Finance in recent years

UK, year ending March 2011 to year ending March 2019

Source: UK Finance
Download this chart
Image .csv .xls

Latest estimates show a rise in fraud, mainly driven by increases in consumer and retail fraud. The CSEW provides the best indication of the volume of fraud offences experienced by the general population as it captures the more frequent lower-harm cases that are likely to go unreported to the authorities.

! Warning The CSEW was recently extended to cover fraud. Comparisons over time are based on limited data points, therefore caution must be taken in interpreting early trends.

Computer misuse

The fall in estimates of computer misuse offences was mainly driven by declines in the numbers of computer virus incidents. The CSEW is the best source for measuring the volume of computer misuse offences experiened by the general population as it captures offences that go unreported

! Warning The CSEW was recently extended to cover computer misuse. Comparisons over time are based on limited data points, therefore caution must be taken in interpreting early trends.

3. Crime data

Dataset | Released on 19 October 2017
The data contained in these tables are from four sources: Crime Survey for England and Wales, Home Office police recorded crime, the National Fraud Intelligence Bureau and the Ministry of Justice Criminal Justice Statistics Quarterly Update.

Crime in England and Wales: Quarterly data tables
Dataset | Released on 19 October 2017
Data from Crime Survey for England and Wales (CSEW) and Home Office police recorded crime broken down into quarterly time periods.

Back to table of contents

4. Glossary

Violent crime

Covers a range of offence types from minor assaults, such as pushing and shoving that result in no physical harm, to murder. This includes offences where the victim was intentionally stabbed, punched, kicked, pushed or jostled, as well as offences where the victim was threatened with violence whether or not there is any injury.

Sharp instrument

A sharp instrument is any object that pierces the skin (or in the case of a threat, is capable of piercing the skin), for example, a broken bottle.

Police area

A police area is the area for which a territorial police force in the United Kingdom is responsible for policing.

Assault with injury and assault with intent to cause serious harm

Offences include injury resulting in permanent disability; more than minor permanent disfigurement; broken bones; fractured skull; compound fractures; substantial loss of blood; internal injury; lengthy treatment or serious psychiatric injury (based on expert evidence); and shock (when accompanied by expert psychological evidence).

A comprehensive guide to crime types and definitions can be found in the User Guide to Crime Statistics for England and Wales.

Back to table of contents

5. Measuring this data

This page is part of our quarterly crime collection, which relies on two main sources of data.

Crime Survey of England and Wales
The Crime Survey of England and Wales (CSEW) is a survey which asks people whether they have been victims of a crime over the past 12 months.

Police recorded crime
Crime that has been reported to the police, and recorded as part of police casework.

Police recorded crime data are not designated as National Statistics.

More information on both these sources can be found in the User guide to crime statistics for England and Wales.

More information on the methodology can be found in the Crime in England and Wales Quality and Methodology Information report.

Back to table of contents

6. Strengths and limitations

The Crime Survey of England and Wales (CSEW) has been consistent since 1981 and is the best source to use when looking at trends over time. It is also a better measurement of crimes which are less likely to be reported to the police, such as sexual offences.

The CSEW does not cover crimes against businesses or those not resident in households and is not well-suited to measuring trends in some of the more harmful crimes that occur in relatively low volumes.

Police recorded crime data are not designated as National Statistics

Police recorded crime is a good measure for understanding how much work police forces are carrying out. It can be affected by changes in policing practices and victims’ willingness to report crime.

Police recorded crime is not a useful way to monitor crime trends, and we do not recommend using it for this.

An increase in the number of crimes recorded by the police does not necessarily mean the level of crime has increased. Find out more about the strengths and limitations of the data used in this bulletin.

For many types of crime, police recorded crime statistics do not provide a reliable measure of levels or trends in crime as they only cover crimes that come to the attention of the police.

Police recorded crime can be affected by changes in policing activity and recording practice and by willingness of victims to report.

For offences that are well recorded by the police, police figures provide a useful supplement to the survey and provide insight into areas that the survey does not cover well.
